context: But, Henry’s law coefficients are not appropriate to characterize the partitioning of VOC between a gas phase and a solid phase, which is the case when the supercooled water is frozen to ice at −25°C. However, all partitioning coefficients determined for the whole temperature range down to −25°C are termed Henry’s law coefficients to ease the reading of the present manuscript. At temperatures above 0°C K AW coefficients of analytes can be calculated after equilibration according to Henry’s law (Bierwagen and Keller, 2001; Arp and Schmidt, 2004; Goss, 2006). For BTEX, MTBE and ETBE, K AW values at 5°C, 15°C, and 25°C were derived from previous reports (Staudinger and Roberts, 2001; Arp and Schmidt, 2004), which also provided data necessary for any adjustment of K AW values with experimental temperatures. Based on the K AW values, the absolute amounts of analytes in the gas phase (n air, nmol) were calculated for 5°C, 15°C, and 25°C according to Eq. (2), and correlated with the measured GC responses at the particular temperature. (2) n air = V air · K AW · n 0 V air · K AW + V liquid where n 0 is the amount (nmol) of analyte in the initial standard solution, V liquid is the volume of the liquid phase (mL), and V air is the volume of the gas phase (mL). With the correlation parameters (from correlation of the measured GC responses and calculated n air values above 0°C) GC responses measured at −5°C, −15°C, and −25°C were transformed to n air values.

The text primarily discusses partitioning coefficients of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) and does not provide any information linking 2-ethoxy-2-methylpropane to autoimmune syndromes or their mechanisms. Thus, their mention appears coincidental rather than relevant.
